analyzed: aham dasa sata byāma  uragam ādāya āgataḥ  mahākāya
translated: “I’ve come with a hundred-league snake,🔽and I’ve brought it to you.
But you don’t tremble at all🔽when you hold that huge body.
But when I hold this little bird,
which is much less dangerous than you,🔽you tremble in fear.
It’s eaten the seeds of the banyan,
the silk-cotton tree, and the fig tree,
and after eating the seeds of the Indian fig tree,
it’ll drop them in my lap.
the seeds it’s eaten will be lost.🔽They’ll grow right here
and increase, even in the great forest.
“You should be suspicious of what should be suspected,
He should protect himself from future danger.🔽The wise man, seeing both worlds,
should protect himself from future danger.”
The Simile of the Thorn-apple Tree is the seventh.
